questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Radial and Musculocutaneous nerve The brachialis muscle, a key flexor of the elbow joint, has a dual nerve supply. The musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6) provides the primary motor innervation to the brachialis, which allows it to perform its main function of elbow flexion. Additionally, the radial nerve (C5, C7) supplies a small lateral portion of the brachialis. This dual innervation is unique and highlights the functional integration of this muscle in elbow movement, ensuring that it remains effective even if one of these nerves is impaired.

questions.text: Artery present in the anatomical snuff box is â€“
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Radial artery The radial artery passes through the anatomical snuff box, a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the wrist. The anatomical snuff box is bordered by the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis on the lateral side, and the extensor pollicis longus tendon on the medial side. The floor of the snuff box is formed by the scaphoid and trapezium bones. The radial artery runs deep in this area, contributing to the vascular supply of the hand, specifically forming part of the deep palmar arch. Its presence in the snuff box makes it easily palpable in this region and clinically significant. Incorrect Responses: (B) Ulnar artery The ulnar artery does not pass through the anatomical snuff box. Instead, it travels along the medial side of the forearm and wrist, supplying the superficial palmar arch and other structures of the medial hand. It has no anatomical relation to the snuff box. (C) Interosseous artery The interosseous arteries (anterior and posterior) arise from the ulnar artery and supply the forearm muscles. They are not located near the anatomical snuff box and do not contribute to its vascular structures. (D) None This is incorrect because the radial artery is clearly present in the anatomical snuff box, making "None" an incorrect option.

questions.text: Structures piercing clavipectoral fascia are all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Basilic vein The basilic vein does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia. This vein is located on the medial side of the arm and drains into the axillary vein. It is not anatomically related to the clavipectoral fascia and does not pass through it, making it the correct exception in this question. Incorrect Responses: (A) Cephalic vein The cephalic vein is a superficial vein located on the lateral side of the arm. It passes through the deltopectoral groove and pierces the clavipectoral fascia to drain into the axillary vein. Its pathway makes it a structure that pierces the clavipectoral fascia. (B) Thoracoacromial artery The thoracoacromial artery, a branch of the axillary artery, pierces the clavipectoral fascia to supply the pectoral muscles and surrounding areas. This artery is a significant structure associated with the clavipectoral fascia. (C) Lateral pectoral nerve The lateral pectoral nerve, a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, pierces the clavipectoral fascia to innervate the pectoralis major muscle. Its anatomical course includes passing through this fascia.

questions.text: Structure piercing the clavipectoral fascia is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cephalic vein The cephalic vein is a superficial vein of the upper limb that pierces the clavipectoral fascia to enter the axillary vein. The clavipectoral fascia is a connective tissue layer located between the clavicle and the pectoralis minor muscle. The cephalic vein passes through the deltopectoral groove and then through the clavipectoral fascia before draining into the axillary vein. This makes it a key structure piercing the fascia and directly associated with it. Incorrect Responses: (A) Basilic vein The basilic vein does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia. It is another superficial vein of the upper limb but follows a different path, running medially along the arm and eventually joining the brachial vein to form the axillary vein. (C) Superior Thoracic artery The superior thoracic artery, a branch of the first part of the axillary artery, supplies the upper thoracic wall and parts of the pectoral muscles. However, it does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia. (D) Musculophrenic nerve The musculophrenic nerve does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia. It is primarily involved in innervating the diaphragm and parts of the intercostal muscles, and its anatomical pathway is unrelated to the fascia.

choices.text: Lies at level of distal palmar crease
Completed by deep branch of ulnar artery

questions.text: Which is correct regarding deep palmar arch
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Completed by deep branch of ulnar artery The deep palmar arch is a vascular structure located in the palm of the hand. It is primarily formed by the radial artery, but it is completed medially by the deep branch of the ulnar artery. This anatomical feature is significant because it establishes an important collateral circulation in the hand. The deep palmar arch gives rise to the palmar metacarpal arteries, which anastomose with the common palmar digital arteries derived from the superficial palmar arch. Incorrect Responses: (A) Superficial to lumbricals This statement is incorrect because the deep palmar arch lies deep to the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus and the lumbricals. The superficial palmar arch, not the deep palmar arch, is closer to the surface and more superficial in the palm. (B) Lies at the level of the distal palmar crease The deep palmar arch is located approximately at the level of the proximal palmar crease, not the distal palmar crease. The distal palmar crease is closer to the superficial palmar arch. (D) Gives 3 interdigital arteries The deep palmar arch primarily gives off palmar metacarpal arteries, not interdigital arteries. The interdigital arteries are branches of the common palmar digital arteries, which originate from the superficial palmar arch, not the deep palmar arch.

questions.text: Axial artery of upper limb is derived from -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 7th cervical intersegmental artery During embryonic development, the axial artery forms as a continuation of the 7th cervical intersegmental artery. This artery contributes to the formation of the major vascular supply of the upper limb, including the subclavian, axillary, brachial, radial, and ulnar arteries. As the limb buds grow, the axial artery elongates and branches to supply the developing limb. Its derivation from the 7th cervical intersegmental artery is crucial for proper upper limb vascularization.

questions.text: Blood supply of breast is from all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thoracodorsal branch of subscapular artery The thoracodorsal artery is a branch of the subscapular artery, itself a branch of the axillary artery. Its primary role is to supply the latissimus dorsi muscle and parts of the posterior thoracic wall. While it is related anatomically to the thoracic region, it does not significantly contribute to the vascular supply of the breast tissue. Incorrect Responses: (A) Internal mammary artery The internal mammary (also called internal thoracic) artery, a branch of the subclavian artery, is a significant supplier of blood to the breast. Its perforating branches pierce the intercostal spaces and provide direct blood flow to the medial portion of the breast. (B) Intercostal artery The posterior intercostal arteries, originating from the thoracic aorta, contribute to the blood supply of the breast via lateral perforating branches. These branches supply the lateral aspect of the breast and contribute to its vascular network. (D) Thoraco-acromial artery The thoraco-acromial artery, a branch of the second part of the axillary artery, contributes to the blood supply of the breast through its pectoral branch. This artery supplies the underlying pectoral muscles and also provides vascular support to the breast tissue.

Correct Answer (A) Prevertebral fascia. The axillary sheath is a connective tissue structure that surrounds the brachial plexus, subclavian artery, and subclavian vein as they pass through the axilla. It is derived from the prevertebral fascia, which covers the muscles of the neck and is continuous with the fascial layers around the roots of the brachial plexus. This fascia provides a supportive sheath around the neurovascular structures in the axillary region. Incorrect Responses: B. Clavipectoral fascia: The clavipectoral fascia is a separate structure located beneath the pectoralis major muscle and above the subclavian muscle. It does not contribute to the formation of the axillary sheath, though it does play a role in the anatomy of the upper limb and chest. C. Deep layer of cervical fascia: While the deep cervical fascia provides support to structures in the neck, including the muscles and blood vessels, it is not the source of the axillary sheath. The deep cervical fascia is involved in the overall organization of the neck, but it does not directly contribute to the sheath surrounding the brachial plexus. D. Pretracheal fascia: The pretracheal fascia is a fascial layer in the neck that surrounds the trachea and thyroid gland. It is not involved in the formation of the axillary sheath, which is primarily derived from the prevertebral fascia. The pretracheal fascia has more to do with the anatomy of the respiratory and endocrine structures in the neck.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves accompanies the Profunda brachii artery
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Radial Nerve The radial nerve accompanies the profunda brachii artery (also known as the deep brachial artery) as it travels through the arm. Both structures course together in the spiral (or radial) groove of the humerus, located on the posterior aspect of the bone. The radial nerve supplies the posterior compartment of the arm, which includes the triceps brachii muscle, and it provides sensory innervation to parts of the posterior arm, forearm, and hand. This anatomical relationship is significant as injuries or fractures of the humeral shaft can potentially affect both the radial nerve and the profunda brachii artery due to their proximity in the groove. Incorrect Options: (A) Ulnar Nerve The ulnar nerve does not accompany the profunda brachii artery. It courses medially in the arm and passes posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus before entering the forearm. It is primarily involved in innervating the intrinsic muscles of the hand and some forearm muscles, and its path is unrelated to the profunda brachii artery. (B) Musculocutaneous Nerve The musculocutaneous nerve primarily serves the anterior compartment of the arm, innervating the biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles. It travels through the arm and becomes the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm but does not have any anatomical relationship with the profunda brachii artery. (D) Median Nerve The median nerve travels medially in the arm alongside the brachial artery, not the profunda brachii artery. It continues its course into the forearm and hand, providing motor and sensory innervation. Its trajectory does not involve the posterior compartment of the arm or the radial groove.

choices.text: Deep branch of transverse cervical artery & subscapular artery
Posterior circumflex humeral & circumflex scapular artery

questions.text: In obstruction of second part of axillay artery, the anostomosis between the following artery will maintain the blood supply of upper limb -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Deep branch of transverse cervical artery & subscapular artery When the second part of the axillary artery is obstructed, the blood supply to the upper limb is maintained through collateral circulation involving the scapular anastomosis. This anastomosis includes the deep branch of the transverse cervical artery (also called the dorsal scapular artery) and the subscapular artery. The transverse cervical artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which arises from the subclavian artery, while the subscapular artery is a branch of the third part of the axillary artery. These vessels form a rich network around the scapula, allowing blood to bypass the obstruction in the axillary artery and supply the upper limb. This pathway is crucial because it ensures adequate perfusion to distal structures when the primary flow through the axillary artery is compromised. Incorrect Options: (B) Anterior & posterior circumflex humeral While the anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries form an anastomosis around the surgical neck of the humerus, this network primarily supplies the shoulder joint and the proximal humerus. They do not play a major role in bypassing an obstruction in the second part of the axillary artery since their location is downstream from the site of obstruction. (C) Posterior circumflex humeral & circumflex scapular artery The posterior circumflex humeral artery supplies the shoulder joint and deltoid muscle, while the circumflex scapular artery (a branch of the subscapular artery) contributes to the scapular anastomosis. However, this combination alone does not provide the collateral circulation necessary to bypass the second part of the axillary artery. (D) Suprascapular & anterior circumflex humeral artery The suprascapular artery contributes to the scapular anastomosis, but the anterior circumflex humeral artery primarily supplies the shoulder joint and does not significantly contribute to collateral circulation bypassing the obstruction. Therefore, this pair is not sufficient for maintaining blood flow to the upper limb.

questions.text: The following structures pass through the carpel tunnel except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ulnar Artery The ulnar artery does not pass through the carpal tunnel. Instead, it travels superficially to the flexor retinaculum, along with the ulnar nerve, as part of Guyon's canal (ulnar canal). The carpal tunnel is a narrow fibro-osseous passage in the wrist through which specific tendons and the median nerve pass. Since the ulnar artery is outside the carpal tunnel, it is not part of the structures that traverse this space, making option (B) the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Median Nerve The median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel along with the flexor tendons. It is the main nerve that provides motor and sensory innervation to parts of the hand. Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel leads to carpal tunnel syndrome, highlighting its importance in this anatomical structure. (C) Flexor Carpi Radialis Tendon The flexor carpi radialis tendon passes through the carpal tunnel, although it has a separate compartment within the flexor retinaculum. It plays a role in wrist flexion and radial deviation and is one of the structures associated with the carpal tunnel anatomy. (D) Flexor Pollicis Longus Tendon The flexor pollicis longus tendon passes through the carpal tunnel. This tendon enables flexion of the thumb at the interphalangeal joint and is essential for grasping and fine motor movements involving the thumb.

choices.text: Ascending branch of anterior circumflex artery
Ascending branch of posterior circumflex artery

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ascending Branch of Anterior Circumflex Artery The bicipital groove, also known as the intertubercular sulcus, is a groove on the proximal humerus where the long head of the biceps brachii tendon lies. The ascending branch of the anterior circumflex humeral artery runs along this groove, supplying blood to the head of the humerus and surrounding structures. This artery is a key component in the blood supply to the shoulder joint and its associated muscles. Incorrect Options: (A) Coracobrachialis Muscle The coracobrachialis muscle is not located in the bicipital groove. It originates from the coracoid process of the scapula and inserts on the humerus, but it does not pass through or reside in the bicipital groove. Thus, option (A) is incorrect. (C) Ascending Branch of Posterior Circumflex Artery The ascending branch of the posterior circumflex humeral artery does not pass through the bicipital groove. This artery runs through the quadrangular space, supplying the deltoid and teres minor muscles, and does not contribute to the vascular supply in the bicipital groove. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect. (D) Radial Artery The radial artery does not pass through the bicipital groove. It is a major artery of the forearm and wrist, branching from the brachial artery and traveling along the lateral aspect of the forearm. The radial artery is not associated with the bicipital groove, making option (D) incorrect.

questions.text: Interosseus membrane between radius and ulna is pierced by which structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anterior interosseous artery. The interosseous membrane between the radius and ulna serves as a key connective structure in the forearm, allowing for the attachment of muscles and facilitating the transfer of forces. Several structures pass through this membrane, but the anterior interosseous artery, which is a branch of the ulnar artery, pierces the interosseous membrane. This artery travels along the anterior side of the membrane, supplying the deep muscles of the forearm, including the flexor muscles. Therefore, the anterior interosseous artery is the correct answer as it directly passes through the interosseous membrane. Evaluation of Each Option: A. Posterior interosseous nerve Incorrect The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve, and it innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm. However, this nerve does not pierce the interosseous membrane. Instead, it travels on the posterior side of the membrane, in the space between the radius and ulna, and does not pass through it. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Posterior interosseous artery Incorrect The posterior interosseous artery is a branch of the common interosseous artery, which itself arises from the ulnar artery. However, it is the anterior interosseous artery that pierces the interosseous membrane, not the posterior one. The posterior interosseous artery runs along the back of the membrane and does not pass through it. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Anterior interosseous nerve Incorrect The anterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the median nerve that innervates the deep muscles of the forearm, such as the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus. However, the anterior interosseous nerve does not pierce the interosseous membrane; rather, it runs alongside the anterior interosseous artery, which is the structure that pierces the membrane. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which branch of subclavian artery contributes to scapular anastomosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C And D) Thyrocervical trunk and Dorsal scapular artery. The scapular anastomosis is a network of blood vessels that provides collateral circulation around the shoulder region, especially when the subclavian artery or its branches are compromised. The thyrocervical trunk and the dorsal scapular artery both contribute to this anastomosis. The thyrocervical trunk is a branch of the subclavian artery that gives rise to the transverse cervical artery and suprascapular artery, both of which supply the scapular region and contribute to the anastomosis around the scapula. The dorsal scapular artery, which can either arise from the subclavian artery or the transverse cervical artery, supplies the rhomboid muscles and contributes to the blood supply around the scapula. These two arteries are key players in the scapular anastomosis, ensuring blood flow to the shoulder area when other major vessels may be obstructed. Evaluation of Each Option: A. Vertebral artery Incorrect The vertebral artery primarily supplies the cervical spine and the brain, rather than contributing directly to the scapular anastomosis. It ascends through the transverse foramina of the cervical vertebrae, and while it is important for vertebral circulation, it does not have a direct role in the scapular anastomosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Internal thoracic artery Incorrect The internal thoracic artery arises from the subclavian artery and supplies the anterior chest wall and the breast. While it plays a crucial role in supplying structures in the thoracic region, it does not directly contribute to the scapular anastomosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Branches of brachial artery are all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Radial collateral. The radial collateral is not a direct branch of the brachial artery; it is a branch of the profunda brachii artery (also known as the deep brachial artery), which itself is a branch of the brachial artery. The radial collateral artery contributes to the blood supply around the elbow joint by anastomosing with other arteries, but it is not a direct branch of the brachial artery itself. Incorrect Responses: A. Profunda brachii: The profunda brachii (deep brachial artery) is a major branch of the brachial artery. It supplies the posterior compartment of the arm, including the triceps and the elbow joint. It also gives off the radial collateral artery and other smaller branches. This option is a valid branch of the brachial artery. B. Superior ulnar collateral: The superior ulnar collateral artery is indeed a branch of the brachial artery. It travels along the medial side of the arm and supplies the elbow joint and the forearm. This artery is a key branch for collateral circulation around the elbow joint. C. Inferior ulnar collateral: The inferior ulnar collateral artery is another branch of the brachial artery. It runs inferiorly to supply the elbow and forearm. Like the superior ulnar collateral, it is an important vessel in the circulation around the elbow joint.

choices.text: 2nd part of subclavian artery with 2nd part of axillary artery
1st part of subclavian artery with 3rd part of axillary artery
3rd part of subclavian artery with 1st part of axillary artery
3rd part of subclavian artery with 3rd part of axillary artery

questions.text: Anastomosis around the shoulder is for connection of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1st part of subclavian artery with 3rd part of axillary artery. The anastomosis around the shoulder involves the 1st part of the subclavian artery and the 3rd part of the axillary artery. Specifically, the dorsal scapular artery (branching from the 1st part of the subclavian artery) and the subscapular artery (branching from the 3rd part of the axillary artery) create an important vascular connection. This anastomosis ensures collateral circulation around the shoulder joint, which is particularly important in cases of blockage or narrowing of major arteries, such as in the subclavian or axillary arteries.
